sources.name: Greece Level 1 Habitat Map 2020 vs S2 with NUTS statistics

meta.description: Natural ecosystem types in 2020 based on the EUNIS 2021 habitat type hierarchy, with statistics using Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics (NUTS) boundaries.

categories.label: Grasslands and lands dominated by forbs, mosses or lichens
Inland habitats with no or little soil and mostly with sparse vegetation
Constructed, industrial or other Artificial types

sources.name: World Cover 2020 with NUTS statistics

meta.description: A 10 meter resolution global land cover product for the year 2020, developed and validated in near-real time based on Sentinel-1 and Sentinel-2 data.  Data is provided with statistics for NUTS (Nomenclature of territorial units for statistics) boundaries.  Select the "statistics" tab and click on a feature to view.

sources.name: World Cover 2021 with NUTS statistics

meta.description: A 10 meter resolution global land cover product for the year 2021, developed and validated in near-real time based on Sentinel-1 and Sentinel-2 data.  Data is provided with statistics for NUTS (Nomenclature of territorial units for statistics) boundaries.  Select the "statistics" tab and click on a feature to view.

sources.name: World Cover 2021 for Natura 2000 areas with statistics

meta.description: Land cover map for 2021 with statistics using Natura 2000 boundaries.  Zoom in until the scale bar shows 10km to show Natura boundaries then click on a Natura area to view statisics.

sources.name: Soil Water Index 1km daily time series - 2015 to present

meta.description: Quantifies the moisture condition at various depths in the soil. Daily observations are available for the continental Europe in the spatial resolution of 1 km and with the temporal extent from January 2015 to present

sources.name: Topsoil Soil Organic Carbon time series - 2018 to 2022

meta.description: Soil Organic Carbon content in the 0-20 cm top soil expressed in g kg-1 for 100 m resolution pixels with constraint layer from World Cover.  Time series dates indicate the end of the two year period over which the data is measured i.e. 2020 (2018 to 2020), 2021 (2019 to 2021), 2022 (2020 to 2022)

sources.name: Topsoil Soil Organic Carbon, uncertainty time series - 2018 to 2022

meta.description: Ancillary layer for uncertainty of pixel values.  Values 0 to 50 indicate low uncertainty, above 50 are high.

sources.name: Topsoil Soil Organic Carbon 2020-22 NUTS statistics

meta.description: Statistics for the Soil Organic Carbon content in the 0-20 cm top soil expressed in g kg-1 for 100 m resolution pixels for the years 2020 to 2022 based on the NUTS (Nomenclature of territorial units for statistics) boundaries.  Select "Statistics" and click on a boundary to view.

sources.name: Topsoil Soil Organic Carbon Natura 2000 areas and 2020-22 statistics

meta.description:
Statistics for Soil Organic Carbon content in the 0-20 cm top soil expressed in g kg-1 for 100 m resolution pixels (2020-2022) using the European Environment Agency Natura 2000 boundaries.

Zoom in until the scale bar reads 20km or less, select the "statistics" tab and click on a feature to view the statistics.

sources.name: Above Ground Biomass, time series - 2017 to 2023

meta.description: Above ground biomass (AGB) in t/ha in 20 m spatial resolution created with the BIOMASAR method using Sentinel-1 and ALOS 2 PALSAR 2 data

sources.name: Below Ground Biomass, time series - 2017 to 2023

meta.description: Below ground biomass (BGB) in t/ha in 20 m spatial resolution created with the BIOMASAR method using Sentinel-1 and ALOS 2 PALSAR 2 data.

sources.name: Growing Stock Volume, time series - 2017 to 2023

meta.description: Growing stock volume (V) in mÂ³/ha in 20 m spatial resolution created with the BIOMASAR method using Sentinel-1 and ALOS 2 PALSAR 2 data.

sources.name: Greece Level 2 Habitat Map 2020 vs S2 with NUTS statistics

meta.description: Natural ecosystem types in 2020 based on the EUNIS 2021 habitat type hierarchy, with statistics using Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics (NUTS) boundaries.

categories.label: Rock cliffs, ledges and shores, including the supralittoral
Valley mires, poor fens and transition mires
Forest fringes and clearings and tall forb stands
Inland salt steppes and salt marshes
Maquis, arborescent matorral and thermo-Mediterranean scrub
Spiny Mediterranean heaths (phrygana, hedgehog-heaths and related coastal cliff vegetation)
Inland cliffs, rock pavements and outcrops
Miscellaneous inland habitats usually with very sparse or no vegetation
Unvegetated or sparsely vegetated gravel bars
Constructed, industrial or other Artificial types

sources.name: Greece Coastal Condition Account 2022

meta.description: Share of artificial impervious area cover (permanent and temporal), present in coastal area that includes ecosystem type coastal beaches, dunes and wetlands for Greece in 2022.

Woodland, forest and other wooded land

Regularly or recently cultivated agricultural, horticultural and domestic habitats

sources.name: Slovakia Level 2 Habitat Map 2020 vs S2 with NUTS statistics

rich fens and calcareous spring mires

heats and related coastal ciff vegetation)

sources.name: Slovakia Wood Provision Service Account 2021

meta.description: Quantification of the supply of wood products from forests, woodlands, or other ecosystems over time for Slovakia in 2021.

sources.name: CLMS NDVI 300m 10 daily time series - 2020 to present

meta.description: NDVI is an indicator of the greenness of the biomes. Every 10-days estimates are available in near real time at global scale in the spatial resolution of about 300 m from July 2020 to the present.

sources.name: FAPAR 1km 10 daily v2 time series - 1999 to 2020

meta.description: Quantifies the fraction of the solar radiation absorbed by live plants for photosynthesis. Every 10-days estimates are available at global scale in the spatial resolution of about 1 km covering the period from 1999 to June 2020 from SPOT/VEGETATION and PROBA-V data.

sources.name: CLMS Forest Monitoring, time series 2020 to 2022

meta.description: Provides at pan-European level in the spatial resolution of 10 m and 100 m the level of tree cover density in a range from 0% to 100%

sources.name: Portugal Land Cover Map - time series 2018 to 2023

meta.description: Trends in land cover between 2018 and 2023 are evaluated based on an automated algorithm to map land cover dynamics at 10 m resolution that combines deep learning and a pixel classifier on pre-processed Sentinel-2 imagery and ancillary input layer.

sources.name: Portugal Land Cover Degradation between 2018 & 2023

meta.description: Trends in land cover between 2018 and 2023 are evaluated based on an automated algorithm to map land cover dynamics at 10 m resolution that combines deep learning and a pixel classifier on pre-processed Sentinel-2 imagery and ancillary input layer

sources.name: Portugal Land Cover - Trends in Carbon Stocks

meta.description: Trends in carbon stocks from SEN4LDN project.

sources.name: DEM
Austria Wind Power Density at 100m

meta.description: The wind power density (w m 2) is a measure of the available wind resource at 100 meters height. Higher wind power density indicates greater wind power potential.  Constraints allow the data to be filtered by multiple criteria.

sources.name: Austria Land Cover

meta.description: World Cover data resampled for use as constraint layer for Austria GTIF datasets.

sources.name: Saddleworth Moor UK - Peatland Classification

meta.description: The WorldPeatland method for mapping peatland extent involves the use of multitemporal composites of Sentinel-1 Ground Range Detected (GRD) radar data and Sentinel-2 surface reflectance imagery, trained using a reference peatland agreement map

sources.name: Saddleworth Moor, UK - Trends in Water Level

meta.description: This dataset provides water level trend products (in mm/yr), including long-term trends derived from the S1S2SMAPL4 and SMAPL4 products, as well as human-induced water level trends estimated from their difference. Negative values indicate declining water levels, while positive values indicate rising levels. Long-term trends were calculated averaging yearly values from May through September in the Northern Hemisphere and over the full year in the tropical zone. or more reliable information, see "Trends in water level â high quality only" which only shows high quality grid cells.

sources.name: Saddleworth Moor, UK - Sentinel 2 ARD time series

meta.description: Selected monthly scenes of Sentinel 2 Analysis Ready Data for the Saddleworth Area, from the UK EO Data Hub platform.

attribution.text: Sentinel 2 ARD via UK EO Data Hub

sources.name: Saddleworth Moor, UK - Sentinel 2 NDVI time series

meta.description: Selected monthly scenes of Sentinel 2 Analysis Ready Data visualised as NDVI for the Saddleworth Area, from the UK EO Data Hub platform.

attribution.text: Sentinel 2 ARD via UK EO Data Hub

sources.name: World Settlement Evolution

meta.description: The World Settlement Footprint (WSFÂ®) Evolution is a 30m resolution dataset outlining the global settlement extent on a yearly basis from 1985 to 2015.

sources.name: World Settlement Footprints - 2015 to 2019 time series

meta.description: The World Settlement Footprint (WSFÂ®) is a 10m resolution binary mask outlining the extent of human settlements globally derived by means of 2015 and 2019 multitemporal Sentinel-1 (S1) and Sentinel-2 (S2) imagery.

sources.name: Austria Annual Solar Power Potential

meta.description: Global horizontal irradiation (kWh/mÂ²/day), annual average. The greater amount of solar irradiation, the more electricity can be generated by a solar cell module. Selecting area with high solar potential contributes significantly to the desired efficiency and economic feasibility of a solar power project.

sources.name: Photovoltaic Farm Detection Workflow

meta.description: Detection workflow for mapping solar farms using Sentinel-2 imagery in an openEO process.   This workflow includes pre-processing steps such as cloud masking, gap filling, outliers filtering as well as feature extraction

attribution.text: Alasawedah, M., Claus, M., Jacob, A., Griffiths, P., Dries, J., and Lippens, S
